message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Shaping of microbial phenotypes by trade-offs
Paper Abstract: Abstract Growth rate maximization is an important fitness strategy for microbes. However, the wide distribution of slow-growing oligotrophic microbes in ecosystems suggests that rapid growth is often not favored across ecological environments. In many circumstances, there exist trade-offs between growth and other important traits (e.g., adaptability and survival) due to physiological and proteome constraints. Investments on alternative traits could compromise growth rate and microbes need to adopt bet-hedging strategies to improve fitness in fluctuating environments. Here we review the mechanistic role of trade-offs in controlling bacterial growth and further highlight its ecological implications in driving the emergences of many important ecological phenomena such as co-existence, population heterogeneity and oligotrophic/copiotrophic lifestyles.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "oligotrophic microorganisms"

Links: [{"title":"Oligotroph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oligotroph"},{"title":"Copiotroph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copiotroph"},{"title":"Trophic state index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trophic_state_index"},{"title":"Microbial loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_loop"},{"title":"Terriglobus roseus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terriglobus_roseus"},{"title":"Picoplankton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Picoplankton"},{"title":"South Pacific Gyre - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Pacific_Gyre"},{"title":"Acidobacteriota - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acidobacteriota"},{"title":"Eutrophication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eutrophication"},{"title":"Photoheterotroph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photoheterotroph"}]

Here are the search results for oligotrophic microorganisms:

## Definition and Characteristics

An oligotroph is an organism that can live in an environment that offers very low levels of nutrients.(no content)Oligotrophs are characterized by slow growth, low rates of metabolism, and generally low population density.

## Environments

Oligotrophic environments include deep oceanic sediments, caves, glacial and polar ice, deep subsurface soil, aquifers, ocean waters, and leached soils.(no content)The term "oligotrophic" is commonly used to describe terrestrial and aquatic environments with very low concentrations of nitrates, iron, phosphates, and carbon sources.

## Examples and Adaptations

Examples of oligotrophic organisms are the bacterium "Candidatus Pelagibacter communis", which is the most abundant organism in the ocean, and lichens, with their extremely low metabolic rate.(no content)Members of the Acidobacteriota phylum have been considered oligotrophic bacteria due to high abundances in low organic carbon environments.(no content)Oligotrophs have acquired survival mechanisms that involve the expression of genes during periods of low nutrient conditions, which has allowed them to find success in various environments.

## Comparison to Copiotrophs

Oligotrophs may be contrasted with copiotrophs, which prefer nutritionally rich environments.(no content)Oligotrophs can outcompete copiotrophs in low-nutrient environments. This causes low-nutrient conditions to continue for extended periods of time, making it difficult for copiotrophs to sustain life.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Coexistence theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coexistence_theory"},{"title":"Storage effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storage_effect"},{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"},{"title":"Ecological niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_differentiation"},{"title":"Coexistence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coexistence"},{"title":"Limiting similarity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limiting_similarity"},{"title":"Relative nonlinearity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_nonlinearity"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowding_out_(biology)"},{"title":"Hutchinson's rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hutchinson's_rule"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of species coexistence ecology based on the search results:

## Core Concepts

Coexistence theory explains the stable coexistence of species as an interaction between two opposing forces: fitness differences between species, which should drive the best-adapted species to exclude others within a particular ecological niche, and stabilizing mechanisms, which maintains diversity.

## Key Mechanisms

Two qualitatively different processes can help species to coexist: a reduction in average fitness differences between species or an increase in niche differentiation between species. These two factors have been termed equalizing and stabilizing mechanisms, respectively.

**Stabilizing Mechanisms:** Stabilizing mechanisms promote coexistence by concentrating intraspecific competition relative to interspecific competition. Resource partitioning (a type of niche differentiation) is a stabilizing mechanism because interspecific competition is reduced when different species primarily compete for different resources.

**Storage Effect:** The storage effect is a coexistence mechanism proposed in the ecological theory of species coexistence. The theory proposes one way for multiple species to coexist: in a changing environment, no species can be the best under all conditions. Instead, each species must have a unique response to varying environmental conditions, and a way of buffering against the effects of bad years.

## The Competitive Exclusion Principle

In ecology, the competitive exclusion principle, sometimes referred to as Gause's law, is a proposition that two species which compete for the same limited resource cannot coexist at constant population sizes. However, for poorly understood reasons, competitive exclusion is rarely observed in natural ecosystems, and many biological communities appear to violate Gause's law.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "growth rate biology"

Links: [{"title":"Growth rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Growth_rate"},{"title":"Biological exponential growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_exponential_growth"},{"title":"Growth curve (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Growth_curve_(biology)"},{"title":"Population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics"},{"title":"Exponential growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_growth"},{"title":"Plant growth analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_growth_analysis"},{"title":"Relative growth rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_growth_rate"},{"title":"Cell growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cell_growth"},{"title":"Bacterial growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacterial_growth"},{"title":"Population ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about growth rate in biology:

## Overview

Growth rate refers to the rate of growth in any biological system.(no content)A growth curve is an empirical model of the evolution of a quantity over time, and growth curves are widely used in biology for quantities such as population size or biomass in population ecology and demography, as well as individual body height or biomass in physiology for growth analysis of individuals.

## Types of Growth Rates

**Relative Growth Rate (RGR):** Relative growth rate (RGR) is growth rate relative to size - that is, a rate of growth per unit time, as a proportion of its size at that moment in time.(no content)The Absolute Growth Rate (AGR) is the temporal rate of change of size (mass).

**Exponential vs. Logistic Growth:** Biological exponential growth is the unrestricted growth of a population of organisms, occurring when resources in its habitat are unlimited.(no content)As resources become more limited, the growth rate tapers off, and eventually, once growth rates are at the carrying capacity of the environment, the population size will taper off. This S-shaped curve observed in logistic growth is a more accurate model than exponential growth for observing real-life population growth of organisms.

## Factors Affecting Growth

Environmental factors influence rate of bacterial growth such as acidity (pH), temperature, water activity, macro and micro nutrients, oxygen levels, and toxins.(no content)Cell growth occurs when the overall rate of cellular biosynthesis (production of biomolecules or anabolism) is greater than the overall rate of cellular degradation.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "copiotrophic bacteria nutrition"

Links: [{"title":"Copiotroph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copiotroph"},{"title":"Oligotroph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oligotroph"},{"title":"Saprotrophic nutrition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saphrotrophic_nutrition"},{"title":"Phototroph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phototrophic_bacteria"},{"title":"Primary nutritional groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_nutritional_groups"},{"title":"Saprotrophic bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saprotrophic_bacteria"},{"title":"Hemibiotrophs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemibiotrophs"},{"title":"Bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteria"},{"title":"Microbial metabolism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_metabolism"},{"title":"Heterotroph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heterotroph"}]

Based on the search results, here's what copiotrophic bacteria nutrition entails:

## Definition
A copiotroph is an organism found in environments rich in nutrients, particularly carbon. They are the opposite to oligotrophs, which survive in much lower carbon concentrations.

## Nutritional Characteristics
Copiotrophic organisms tend to grow in high organic substrate conditions, and they grow in organic substrate conditions up to 100x higher than oligotrophs.(no content)Due to this substrate concentration inclination, copiotrophs are often found in nutrient rich waters near coastlines or estuaries.

## Growth Pattern
In these high resource environments, copiotrophs exhibit a "feast-and-famine" lifestyle. They utilize the available nutrients in the environment rapidly resulting in nutrient depletion which forces them to starve.(no content)Copiotrophs are larger than oligotrophs and need more energy, requiring larger concentrations of substrate for survival.

## Metabolic Adaptations
Copiotrophs are characterized by a high maximum growth rate. This high growth rate allows for copiotrophs to have a larger genome and cell size than their oligotrophic counterparts.(no content)Copiotrophs are motile. Copiotrophs can have external organelles such as flagella that extend out of a microbe's cell to facilitate movement. Copiotrophs are also chemotactic, meaning they can detect nutrients in the environment.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about population heterogeneity:

## Overview

Heterogeneity relates to the lack of uniformity in a substance, process or image. A homogeneous feature is uniform in composition or character, while a heterogeneous one is distinctly nonuniform in at least one quality.

## Key Applications and Contexts

**In Statistics and Surveys:**
Simple population surveys may assume that responses will be homogeneous across the whole population, while assessing homogeneity involves examining whether the responses of certain identifiable subpopulations differ from those of others.

**In Ecology and Spatial Distribution:**
A population showing spatial heterogeneity is one where various concentrations of individuals of a species are unevenly distributed across an area.

**In Genetics:**
Genetic heterogeneity refers to the variety of genetic differences present within a population, which is crucial for a species' ability to adapt to changing environments.(no content)In general, an average of 85% of genetic variation exists within local populations, ~7% is between local populations within the same continent, and ~8% of variation occurs between large groups living on different continents.

**In Medical/Clinical Settings:**
A genetic or allelic heterogeneous condition is one where the same disease or condition can be caused, or contributed to, by varying different genes or alleles.

The concept of population heterogeneity is important across multiple fields, from biology and statistics to economics and medicine.

Web search results for query: "bet-hedging strategy evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Bet hedging (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bet_hedging_(biology)"},{"title":"Hedge (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedge_(finance)"},{"title":"Emotional hedge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotional_hedge"},{"title":"Evolutionarily stable strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionarily_stable_strategy"},{"title":"Betting strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betting_strategy"},{"title":"Prediction market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prediction_market"},{"title":"Matched betting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matched_betting"},{"title":"Alternative beta - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_beta"},{"title":"Macrotera portalis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macrotera_portalis"},{"title":"Terminal investment hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_investment_hypothesis"}]

Based on the search results, I found information about bet-hedging strategy evolution, primarily in the biological context:

## Bet-Hedging Strategy Evolution in Biology

Bet hedging is understood to be a mode of response to environmental change, where adaptations that allow organisms to survive in fluctuating environmental conditions provide an evolutionary advantage.

### Three Categories of Bet-Hedging Strategies

There are three categories (strategies) of bet-hedging: "conservative" bet-hedging, "diversified" bet-hedging, and "adaptive coin flipping." In conservative bet hedging, individuals lower their expected fitness in exchange for a lower variance in fitness.

### Evolution and Selection

While a bet hedging trait may not be optimal for any one environment, this is outweighed by the benefits of higher fitness across a variety of environments. Therefore, bet hedging alleles tend to be favored in more variable environments.

### Recent Theoretical Development

More recently, Yasui (2022) proposed a fundamental redefinition of evolutionary bet-hedging, arguing for its universality as a core biological principle rather than merely a specific adaptive strategy for unpredictable environments. He redefined bet-hedging as any strategy that maximizes long-term (geometric mean) fitness to avoid extinction, irrespective of a direct trade-off with arithmetic mean fitness.

### Research Models

Experiments in bet hedging using prokaryotic model organisms provide some of the most simplified views of the evolution of bet hedging. As bet hedging involves a stochastic switching between phenotypes across generations, prokaryotes are able to display this phenomenon quite nicely due to their ability to reproduce quickly enough to track evolution in a single population over a short period of time. This rapid rate of reproduction has allowed for the study of bet hedging in labs through experimental evolution models.

Web search results for query: "ecological trade-offs biology"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Competition–colonization trade-off - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition–colonization_trade-off"},{"title":"Trade-off - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade-off"},{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle"},{"title":"Colonisation (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonisation_(biology)"},{"title":"Plant strategies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_strategies"},{"title":"Behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Economics of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Ecological network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_network"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ecological trade-offs in biology:

## Definition and Core Concept

In biology, a trade-off occurs when a beneficial change in one trait is linked to a detrimental change in another trait.(no content)In evolutionary biology, an evolutionary trade-off is a situation in which evolution cannot advance one part of a biological system without distressing another part of it, where one trait increases in fitness at the expense of decreased fitness in another trait.

## Causes of Ecological Trade-offs

Due to resource limitations (e.g. energy, habitat/space, time) the simultaneous optimization of two traits cannot be achieved.(no content)Another commonly accepted cause of evolutionary trade-offs is that the characteristics of increasing the fitness in one trait negatively affects the fitness of another trait.

## Life History Trade-offs

Life history trade-offs can be defined as the decrease in fitness (essentially, lifetime reproductive success) caused by one life history trait as a result of the increase in fitness caused by a different life history trait. Common examples include:

- A classic example is a negative relationship between the age and the size of maturity, where growth rates are negatively correlated with maximal size so that the fastest growing individuals produce the smallest adults and slowly growing individuals produce large adults.
- Another classic example is the trade-off between energy investment in reproduction versus survival.

## Competition-Colonization Trade-off

In ecology, the competition–colonization trade-off is a stabilizing mechanism that has been proposed to explain species diversity in some biological systems, especially those that are not in equilibrium.(no content)Some species are particularly good at colonizing while others have well-established survival abilities, with two species able to coexist if one had impeccable competition skill and the other was excellent at colonizing.

## Plant Strategy Trade-offs

Plants must make trade-offs when responding to their environment.(no content)Plants develop strategies that demonstrate resource trade-offs between growth, reproduction, and maintenance.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "ecological trade-offs biology"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Competition–colonization trade-off - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition–colonization_trade-off"},{"title":"Trade-off - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade-off"},{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle"},{"title":"Colonisation (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonisation_(biology)"},{"title":"Plant strategies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_strategies"},{"title":"Behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Economics of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Ecological network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_network"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ecological trade-offs in biology:

## Definition and Core Concept

In biology, a trade-off occurs when a beneficial change in one trait is linked to a detrimental change in another trait.(no content)In evolutionary biology, an evolutionary trade-off is a situation in which evolution cannot advance one part of a biological system without distressing another part of it, where one trait increases in fitness at the expense of decreased fitness in another trait.

## Causes of Ecological Trade-offs

Due to resource limitations (e.g. energy, habitat/space, time) the simultaneous optimization of two traits cannot be achieved.(no content)Another commonly accepted cause of evolutionary trade-offs is that the characteristics of increasing the fitness in one trait negatively affects the fitness of another trait.

## Life History Trade-offs

Life history trade-offs can be defined as the decrease in fitness (essentially, lifetime reproductive success) caused by one life history trait as a result of the increase in fitness caused by a different life history trait. Common examples include:

- A classic example is a negative relationship between the age and the size of maturity, where growth rates are negatively correlated with maximal size so that the fastest growing individuals produce the smallest adults and slowly growing individuals produce large adults.
- Another classic example is the trade-off between energy investment in reproduction versus survival.

## Competition-Colonization Trade-off

In ecology, the competition–colonization trade-off is a stabilizing mechanism that has been proposed to explain species diversity in some biological systems, especially those that are not in equilibrium.(no content)Some species are particularly good at colonizing while others have well-established survival abilities, with two species able to coexist if one had impeccable competition skill and the other was excellent at colonizing.

## Plant Strategy Trade-offs

Plants must make trade-offs when responding to their environment.(no content)Plants develop strategies that demonstrate resource trade-offs between growth, reproduction, and maintenance.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors, edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
## Analysis Complete ✅

I have successfully analyzed the paper "Shaping of microbial phenotypes by trade-offs" and extracted all key entities. Here's what was completed:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: Survey (literature review and overview)
- The paper reviews mechanistic roles and ecological implications rather than proposing new methods

### Extracted Triples (7 total)
All triples relate to concepts and methods that the paper uses:

1. **Bacterial growth** - The core phenomenon the paper reviews
2. **Oligotroph** - Slow-growing microbes discussed throughout
3. **Evolutionary tradeoff** - Central concept explaining phenotypic variation
4. **Bet hedging (biology)** - Strategy for survival in fluctuating environments
5. **Coexistence theory** - Ecological outcome of trade-offs
6. **Population heterogeneity** - Ecological phenomenon emerging from trade-offs
7. **Copiotroph** - Alternative lifestyle discussed in contrast to oligotrophs

### Validation Results
✅ All validation checks passed:
- Valid paper type classification
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct
- 7 triples extracted (6 concepts, 1 method)
- All entities have proper relevance explanations

The triples_output.json file has been successfully updated and validated.
